metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. S. V. Veerappan Chettiar Co.

facts.text: Four persons carried on business in cloth at Virudhunagar in the name and style of S. V. Veerappan Chettiar Co. (the firm).
The firm was registered under Art. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, for the assessment years 1947-48, 1949-50 and 1950-51.
The firm concealed particulars of its income in submitting its returns.
Income-tax Officer, Virudhunagar, by order dated May 20, 1954, imposed penalty of Rs. 20,000/- for 1947-48, Rs. 10,000/- for 1949-50 and Rs. 5,000/- for 1950-51 under s. 28(1)(c).
One partner moved Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras in revision against penalty orders, but without success.
Two partners filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in Madras High Court for writs of certiorari to quash ITO orders dated May 20, 1954 and CIT's revision order.
By agreement between partners, firm stood dissolved on April 13, 1951, and intimation given to ITO.
Firm stood dissolved on May 5, 1953, when one partner died.
High Court accepted petitioners' plea, set aside ITO orders dated May 20, 1954 and CIT's orders declining revision, by judgment dated May 3, 1957.
Assessment order for 1949-50 dated November 10, 1951, with endorsement that action under s. 28 taken for concealment of income.

legal_issues.text: Whether Income-tax Officer has power under s. 28 to impose penalty on a firm after its dissolution by agreement or death of partner.
Whether a registered firm is liable to penalty under s. 28(1)(c) notwithstanding scheme under s. 23(5) where no tax payable by firm.
Whether ITO was satisfied in course of assessment proceedings that firm concealed income for 1949-50.

petitioner_arguments.text: ITO had power under s. 28 to impose penalty even after dissolution, as per s. 44 which applies Chapter IV to discontinued firms.
C.A. Abraham case applies to registered firms as well, approving Mareddy Krishna Reddy (registered firm case).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: C.A. Abraham v. ITO; Mareddy Krishna Reddy v. ITO

petitioner_arguments.text: Registered firm is 'person' under s. 28(1), liable for penalty under cls. (a),(b),(c); proviso (d) clarifies quantum.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 28(1), s. 2(9), General Clauses Act s. 3(42)

petitioner_arguments.text: No tax liability not precondition for penalty; even if no assessable income.
Evidence of satisfaction: endorsement on assessment order.

respondent_arguments.text: No power to impose penalty after dissolution.
C.A. Abraham applies only to unregistered firms.
Registered firm not liable to penalty under s. 28(1)(c) as no tax payable by firm under s. 23(5); penalty only on those liable to tax.
No evidence ITO satisfied in course of proceedings for 1949-50.

court_reasoning.text: ITO has power under s. 28 to impose penalty post-dissolution per s. 44 machinery; assessment includes penalty imposition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 44 applies to all firms, registered or not.

court_reasoning.text: C.A. Abraham applies to registered firms; approved Mareddy (registered firm).
Firm is 'person'; liable under s. 28(1)(a)(b)(c); proviso (d) for quantum.
s. 23(5) is collection method; penalty applicable to registered firm.
Endorsement shows ITO satisfied in course of assessment.

holdings.text: ITO can impose penalty under s. 28(1)(c) on dissolved firm, including registered firm.
Registered firm liable to penalty under s. 28(1)(c) despite no direct tax under s. 23(5).
ITO satisfied in course of proceedings as per endorsement.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam
precedents_cited.relevance: Power to impose penalty post-dissolution under s. 28 and s. 44.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mareddy Krishna Reddy v. Income-tax Officer, Tenali
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied to registered firm dissolved before penalty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khushiram Murarilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Registered firm liable to penalty under s. 28(1)(b); no tax liability precondition.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalty imposition on firm post-dissolution; registered firm liability.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writs of certiorari filed in High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court orders set aside; writ petitions dismissed. Penalty orders of ITO dated May 20, 1954 upheld.
outcome.costs: Costs in this Court and High Court to appellants.

key_quotes.text: the Income-tax Officer had power under s. 28 of the Income-tax Act to impose penalty in the course of assessment of a firm even if the firm stood at the date of the order dissolved by the death of one of its partners.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on post-dissolution penalty power.

key_quotes.text: A firm is manifestly a body of individuals and would therefore fall within the definition of person, and may be exposed to an order for payment of penalty.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: To the imposition of a penalty liability to pay tax by the person against whom the penalty is sought to be imposed is therefore not a condition precedent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects tax liability precondition for registered firms.
